74  To become fully acquainted with the Natural History of any
species, it is requisite;- (1) To study not only its external conformation, but
also its internal organisation; by which alone can the value of
superficial resemblances or differences be duly estimated; (2) To
trace out its entire <u>developmental history</u>, so that the true
relationship of individuals in different stages of evolution may be
appreciated; (3) To compare together a <u>large number</u> of specimens
taken from the same locality, in order to ascertain what is the range of its variation under nearly identical conditions; (4) To search out
its whole <u>Geographical distribution</u>, and to bring into mutual
comparison large numbers of specimens from the remotest regions,
as well as from all the intermediate areas over which it spreads,
in order to determine the range of its variation<s>s</s> under the most
diverse conditions;- and (5) To follow the same course of
comparison throughout its Geological distribution, still relying only
on the information afforded by large numbers of specimens, collected<s>,</s>
(so far as may be possible) from different formations, and from
different geographical areas. - Until the whole of this process shall
